0: Paris attacks suspect Salah Abdeslam has told investigators he was planning new operations from Brussels, Belgium's foreign minister has said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Didier Reynders said that Abdeslam said "he was ready to restart something from Brussels, and it's maybe the reality". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The minister said the authorities are taking the claim seriously because "we found a lot of weapons, heavy weapons in the first investigations, and we have seen a new network of people around him in Brussels". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He added: "We have found more than 30 people involved in the terrorist attacks in Paris, but we are sure that there are others." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Abdeslam was arrested on Friday in a police raid in the Belgian capital, four months after the Paris attacks which left 130 people dead. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He has been charged with "terrorist murder" and now faces extradition to France. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Paris prosecutor Francois Molins said the 26-year-old told investigators he planned to carry out a suicide attack outside the Stade de France, but did not go ahead with his plan. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Abdeslam's lawyer Sven Mary has told Belgian public broadcaster RTBF that he will file a complaint against Mr Molins, accusing him of revealing details of the first interrogation of the suspect to journalists on Saturday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Meanwhile, it has emerged Abdeslam's brother Brahim, who blew himself up at a restaurant as part of the attacks, was buried just a day before his brother was captured. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Salah Abdeslam is believed to be the last surviving member of the 10-man jihadist team that carried out the Paris attacks, which Islamic State claimed responsibility for. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Two more suspects are wanted in connection with the bloodshed - Mohamed Abrini, who became friends with Abdeslam when they were teenagers, and another fugitive known only by a name used on false papers, Soufiane Kayal. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mr Molins said Abdeslam played a "central role" in the attacks, which targeted bars, restaurants, a concert hall and the Stade de France. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Investigators believed he rented rooms in the city to be used by the attackers and a car which he used to drive them to the stadium before heading to Paris' 18th arrondissement. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In the aftermath of the attacks an explosive-filled suicide vest was found in an area where mobile phone signals indicated Abdeslam had been. was NEWLINE_CHAR told
